children.text:
We are given two Java programs to be executed in sequence. First Java program (codeforces_25_A):
  - Reads an integer `n`
  - Reads an array of `n` integers
  - Counts the number of odd and even numbers and records the last index where an odd and even number occurred.
  - If there are more odd numbers, it prints the index of the even number (which is the outlier) and vice versa. Second Java program (atcoder_ABC151_A):
  - Reads a string (a single line)
  - Prints the next character in the alphabet (by taking the first character of the string and adding 1 to it)
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: However, note that the output of the first program is an integer (the index) and the second program expects a string (a single character? but note the input in the second program is a string). But the problem says: the output of each program is used as the input to the next. So the output of the first program (an integer) becomes the input to the second program?
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: That does not match because the second program expects a string. But looking at the second program: it reads a string and then prints the next character. However, if we feed it an integer as a string, then we are reading a string that is a number.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: For example, if the first program outputs "3", then the second program would read the string "3", take the first character '3', and then add 1 to get the character '4'. Then it prints '4'. But the problem says: "the entire sequence" and "behaves identically".

The first program would output "0\n", then the second program would take the first character '0' and output '1'. So we output "0\n1". But wait: the first program in the chain: the array indices are from 1 to n, so the index will never be 0. So we are safe. Steps:

      integer :: n
      integer, allocatable :: array(:)
      integer :: i, odd, even, odd_ind, even_ind, idx
      character(len=20) :: str
      character :: first_char, next_char

      read(*,*) n
      allocate(array(n))
      read(*,*) (array(i), i=1, n)

      ! Now, note: the original Java array is 1-indexed (from 1 to n). Our Fortran array is 1-indexed by default.

      odd = 0; even = 0; odd_ind = 0; even_ind = 0 do i = 1, n
          if (mod(array(i), 2) == 0) then
              even = even + 1
              even_ind = i
          else
              odd = odd + 1
              odd_ind = i
          end if
      end do

      if (odd > even) then
          idx = even_ind
      else
          idx = odd_ind
      end if

      ! Now convert idx to string
      write(str, '(I0)') idx

      ! Get the first character of str
      first_char = str(1:1)

      ! Compute the next character
      next_char = char( ichar(first_char) + 1 )

      ! Output: first the integer (as a string) and a newline, then the next_char without a newline. write(*, '(a)') trim(str)
      write(*, '(a)', advance='no')
children.label: mental_execution

Actually, the second read reads one line and tries to read n integers from that line. If there are not enough, it will continue to the next line? That is compiler dependent? To be safe, we can read one integer per line? But the problem says the same behavior. The original program reads tokens. Alternatively, we can read the entire line for the array? But the problem does not specify. However, the problem says: "the same input". We are reading the same input as the first program. The first program reads tokens. We can do:

            read(*,*) array(i)
        end do

  This will read one integer per line. But the input might be on one line? Actually, the original program:

        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            array[i] = ob.nextInt();
        }

      This reads tokens: it will read the next integer, skipping any whitespace. So it can be on one line or multiple.

children.text:
In Fortran, we can read the entire array from one line if they are there, but if not, it will read from the next lines. We can do:

        read(*,*) (array(i), i=1, n)

      This will read from the next line(s) until it gets n integers. This should match. Therefore, we use that. Code:

      program combined
      implicit none
      integer :: n, i, odd, even, odd_ind, even_ind, idx
      integer, allocatable :: array(:)
      character(len=20) :: str
      character :: first_char, next_char

      ! Read n
      read(*,*) n
      allocate(array(n))

      ! Read the array
      read(*,*) (array(i), i=1, n)

      odd = 0
      even = 0
      odd_ind = 0
      even_ind = 0

      do i = 1, n
          if (mod(array(i), 2) == 0) then
              even = even + 1
              even_ind = i
          else
              odd = odd + 1
              odd_ind = i
          end if
      end do

      if (odd > even) then
          idx = even_ind
      else
          idx = odd_ind
      end if

      ! Convert idx to a string without leading spaces
      write(str, '(I0)') idx

      ! Get the first character of the string
      first_char = str(1:1)

      ! Compute the next character
      next_char = char(ichar(first_char) + 1)

      ! Output: first the integer string and a newline, then the next_char without a newline. write(*, '(a)') trim(str)
      write(*, '(a)', advance='no')
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
next_char

      deallocate(array)
      end program combined

We are given two Java programs to be executed in sequence.

First Java program (codeforces_25_A):
  - Reads an integer `n`
  - Reads an array of `n` integers
  - Counts the number of odd and even numbers and records the last index where an odd and even number occurred.
  - If there are more odd numbers, it prints the index of the even number (which is the outlier) and vice versa.

Second Java program (atcoder_ABC151_A):
  - Reads a string (a single line)
  - Prints the next character in the alphabet (by taking the first character of the string and adding 1 to it)

However, note that the output of the first program is an integer (the index) and the second program expects a string (a single character? but note the input in the second program is a string).

But the problem says: the output of each program is used as the input to the next.

For example, if the first program outputs "3", then the second program would read the string "3", take the first character '3', and then add 1 to get the character '4'. Then it prints '4'.

But the problem says: "the entire sequence" and "behaves identically". However, the two programs are independent and the problem states that the output of the first is the input to the second.

      integer :: n
      integer, allocatable :: array(:)

      character(len=20) :: str

      odd = 0; even = 0; odd_ind = 0; even_ind = 0

              even_ind = i

      write(*, '(a)') trim(str)

      This reads tokens: it will read the next integer, skipping any whitespace. So it can be on one line or multiple.

  In Fortran, we can read the entire array from one line if they are there, but if not, it will read from the next lines. We can do:

        read(*,*) (array(i), i=1, n)

      This will read from the next line(s) until it gets n integers.

  Code:

      program combined
      implicit none
      integer :: n, i, odd, even, odd_ind, even_ind, idx
      integer, allocatable :: array(:)
      character(len=20) :: str
      character :: first_char, next_char

      ! Read n
      read(*,*) n
      allocate(array(n))

      ! Read the array
      read(*,*) (array(i), i=1, n)

      odd = 0
      even = 0
      odd_ind = 0
      even_ind = 0

      do i = 1, n
          if (mod(array(i), 2) == 0) then
              even = even + 1
              even_ind = i
          else
              odd = odd + 1
              odd_ind = i
          end if
      end do

      if (odd > even) then
          idx = even_ind
      else
          idx = odd_ind
      end if

      ! Convert idx to a string without leading spaces
      write(str, '(I0)') idx

      ! Get the first character of the string
      first_char = str(1:1)

      ! Compute the next character
      next_char = char(ichar(first_char) + 1)

      ! Output: first the integer string and a newline, then the next_char without a newline.
      write(*, '(a)') trim(str)
      write(*, '(a)', advance='no') next_char

      deallocate(array)
      end program combined

  But note: the original first program uses 1-indexing for the array and the output index. We are using 1-indexing in the do loop and in storing the index. So it's the same.
